results.title: The Mohammedan world: beginnings and growth
results.creator_credit: John Smart and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Presents scenes of mosques and historic landmarks in cities which are a part of the Mohammedan world; life in Baghdad, Damascus, Cairo and Old Jerusalem; discusses Mohammedanism and traces its development; shows the contribution of Mohammedans to western culture in literature, agriculture, chemistry, mathematics and the industrial arts.

results.title: The Modern prospector
results.creator_credit: Jean-Yves Bigras, Tim Wilson and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Instead of pick and shovel, the modern prospector employs all the resources of science to look for buried treasure. Aerial surveys, airborne magnetometers, instruments to measure the breadth and depth of ore bodies - with these the prospector can provide data to the company geologist to pinpoint the most promising drilling locations.

results.title: The Modern lithographer
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: A detailed study of the techniques of lithographic artists, and the process of duplicating black and white originals by means of direct and offset lithography. The roles of the commercial photographer and the modern printing press in the mass production of attractive art prints, including advertising materials, are shown.

results.title: The Modern infantryman
results.brief_description: Illustrates the role of the infantryman in the modern army. Shows his training in the use of weapons and in tactics, illustrates the three types of battle dress adapted to meet the demands of different climates. The weapons shown include the .303 rifle, light and medium machine gun, flame throwers, hand grenades and anti-tank weapons. Today, the infantry has taken to the air and infantrymen are being trained to become members of paratroop units.

results.title: The Moat monster
results.creator_credit: Sara H Arnaud and Steve Campus Productions
results.brief_description: Infantile anxieties embodied in the apocryphal Moat Monster. Extraordinary document of unrestrained play, profiling a small group of pre-school children and the spontaneous generation of their narrative about the ‘Moat Monster’. Contingent nature of children’s reality finds expression in the creative dynamism of this whimsical drama. Portions of this film appear in a full length film entitled ‘Role Enactment in Children’s Play: a Developmental Overview’. Episode 3 of “Training module on role enactment in children’s play” series.

results.title: The Mississippi River: background for social studies
results.brief_description: Follows a houseboat down the Mississippi River, explaining that the river and its tributaries form a vast network of waterways, linking great agricultural and industrial areas with important cities and ports. The importance of the Mississippi as a drainage basin for more than a third of the continent; its geographic, commercial and historic influence on adjacent lands.

results.title: The Mirror of man
results.brief_description: A statement on behalf of contemporary art. Presents the movement from the first break with classical form to our art expression of today. Paintings used in the film were selected from the 1958 Retrospective Exhibition at the Carnegie Institute at Pittsburgh, which presented a survey of paintings shown at the International Exhibitions of the Institute since 1894. Commentator: Vincent Price

results.title: The Miraculous Mellops. Part 5
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans and Millenium Pictures
results.brief_description: Mr. Dump is not the Grand Baby after all. The Grand Baby passes away and the Moonlings are left to their own devices. Before he disappears, the Grand Baby gives Gamma Jane the secret code which reveals which of the Mellops is to replace him. Michael and Harmony expose Mr. Dump’s illegal activities, and Mr. Dump’s latest money scheme fails. Michael works out the code and reveals which Mellop family member is to return to the Moon as the new Grand Baby. In an energy transference, the new Grand Baby goes to the Moon and Harmony returns home. Gamma Jane and Alpha Ralph leave and Dad goes berserk over the lunar phonebill.

results.title: The Miraculous Mellops. Part 4
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans and Millenium Pictures
results.brief_description: Mr Dump’s waste dump business involves dealings with some very shady characters and strange waste materials. Harmony and Michael are having doubts about the business. The Mellops are trying to find Aunt Jocelyn’s magic toothpaste with the linguistic powers. Sam decides that as the Grand Baby is getting weaker, she will leave her family and return to the Moon as she is convinced that she is the Grand Baby. However the Grand Baby test fails on the Mellops and it appears that Mr. Dump may be the likely candidate.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans and Millenium Pictures

results.title: The Miraculous Mellops. Part 3
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans and Millenium Pictures
results.brief_description: Ralph uses the time-travel vacuum cleaner and returns to the Age of Dinosaurs. The Moon flowers are multiplying and making money for the nursery, but Bill Mellops still does not realise that Jane and Ralph are from the Moon. Harmony and Michael travel to the Moon in the combi, and on their return Mr. Dump steals the van with the intention of using the Moon as a waste dump.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl Zwicky, Posie Graeme-Evans and Millenium Pictures
